column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Buoy an Anchor
#Text=An anchor buoy is the common term for a trip line .
#Text=Anchors can be expensive , but you can save yourself this cost with a homemade trip line .
#Text=If you already have one , they 're relatively easy to deploy and retrieve .
#Text=Be sure to use your trip line safely to prevent unnecessary tangles or damage .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Deploying and Retrieving a Trip Line
#Text=Determine the length of your trip line .
#Text=Use a nautical chart , a depth finder , or another suitable instrument to find the water 's depth at high tide .
#Text=The length of your trip line needs to be at least equal to this depth .
#Text=You never know when you 'll get tall waves because of rough conditions .
#Text=Account for this by adding about 3 ft ( .91 m ) to your minimum length for the line .
#Text=Avoid allowing too much extra line in the water , as this can make it more likely to foul .
#Text=Extra slack can be wrapped around the buoy 's bottom .
#Text=If you plan on being buoyed at this location for a long period of time , make sure your trip line is a little longer than the highest tide ( of all the high tides ) during your anchorage .
#Text=Fasten the trip line to the anchor .
#Text=The cord of your trip line needs to be firmly attached to the crown of the anchor .
#Text=Most anchors will have at least a hole in the fluke or a designated tie-on spot for trip lines .
#Text=If the hole on your anchor for your trip line is rough , you 'll need a shackle so the line does n't chafe and break .
#Text=If your buoy is not already attached , use a firm knot , like a large eye splice , to fasten it to the anchor-opposite end of the rope .
#Text=Spool out the trip line to prevent snags and tangles .
#Text=Gather the cord of the trip line in a coil so it 's easier to manage .
#Text=If necessary , pass the coil under and over the pulpit or rail to prevent it from snagging there .
#Text=Separate the coil in half and set down the half farther away from the float .
#Text=Deploy the trip line .
#Text=Approach your anchorage point carefully .
#Text=While keeping ahold of the half of the coil closest to the float , toss the float overboard to the anchorage point .
#Text=Release the line as you do , so it completely streams into the water .
#Text=Follow the trip line with the anchor .
#Text=Take care during this process to avoid getting the trip line and anchor tangled .
#Text=Lower the anchor as you would normally .
#Text=Make sure to deploy the trip line before dropping anchor , as this will decrease the chances of tangling .
#Text=Retrieve the trip line and anchor .
#Text=Approach the anchor point with your boat .
#Text=Snag and retrieve the buoy of your trip line with a boat hook .
#Text=Retrieve the anchor as per usual – you 'll only need to use the trip line if the anchor is stuck .
#Text=If your anchor does n't budge , it 's time to put your trip line to work .
#Text=In many cases , simply pulling up on the trip line will capsize the anchor and free it .
#Text=Most anchors resist a single direction of travel .
#Text=By adding slack to the anchor line or by pulling in the direction opposite anchor 's resisted direction , you may pop stuck anchors free .
#Text=Maintain and stow your trip line .
#Text=Once the anchor 's on board , it 's time to remove the trip line from the crown .
#Text=After using your trip line , you should rinse it well in clean water .
#Text=Allow the wet line to air dry completely , then return it where it belongs in the anchor locker .
#Text=Making a Simple Trip Line
#Text=Purchase or make a buoy .
#Text=Even a cheap Styrofoam buoy from your local hardware store should work for a trip line anchor buoy .
#Text=Serious boaters or those who frequent deep waters might benefit from sturdier buoys purchased from boat supply stores .
#Text=Make an upcycled buoy from a clean plastic jug .
#Text=You can even paint the jug a bright color to make it easier to spot in the water .
#Text=Cut polypropylene cord for the buoy .
#Text=Not only will polypropylene line withstand harsh conditions better than most other kinds of cordage , it also floats .
#Text=The length of your trip line should be about 3 ft ( .91 m ) longer than the highest tide in your sailing area .
#Text=Choose a bright color of polypropylene cord so you can spot your trip line better in unfavorable conditions .
#Text=After cutting the rope , prevent it from fraying at the cut end with glue or by passing a the flame of a lighter over the cut end to melt it .
#Text=Attach the buoy to the line with a large eye splice .
#Text=Large is the key word here .
#Text=A large eye splice will make snagging your buoy a cinch with a boat hook .
#Text=If you decide to use another kind of knot , make sure it 's sturdy .
#Text=Your trip line wo n't do you much good if the buoy floats away .
#Text=Using Trip Lines Safely
#Text=Write a label on your buoy .
#Text=Especially in crowded conditions , boaters desperate for moorage might take liberties with unmarked buoys .
#Text=Send a clear message that your buoy is currently in use by writing “ Trip line , do n't pick up ” in large letters , along with your boat 's name .
#Text=Avoid using trip lines overnight .
#Text=In the dark , even the most colorful trip lines can be missed .
#Text=This can tangle in a fellow boaters ' propellers , causing trouble for you both .
#Text=Especially if there 's night traffic on the water , you may want to forego a trip line for overnight anchorages .
#Text=Prevent boats from damaging your anchor with a trip line .
#Text=Crowded harbors can be difficult places to maneuver .
#Text=This can sometimes cause other boats to pass uncomfortably close to your anchor and its line .
#Text=Improve visibility of your anchorage point for other boats with a trip line .
#Text=Use a trip line when anchoring in areas with a poor bottom .
#Text=Broken rock or large pieces of coral can trap your anchor stubbornly in cracks and crevices .
#Text=If you 've had your anchor stuck before in the area you 're now anchoring , or if you 're worried it might get stuck , deploy a trip line .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Deploying and Retrieving a Trip Line
#Text=Anchor
#Text=Trip line ( and buoy )
#Text=Making a Simple Trip Line
#Text=Buoy ( or a clean plastic jug )
#Text=Polypropylene cord
#Text=Scissors ( or a knife )
#Text=Tape measure
